meaning_mnemonic: Your magic <radical>yoga</radical> <radical>brush</radical> lets you <kanji>build</kanji> what's in your mind's eye.

If you see a <radical>spirit</radical> with an <radical>axe</radical>, you better <kanji>pray</kanji> for your life. Spirits only hold axes if they're thinking about murder, so pray as hard as you can to try and get it to spare you.

Seeing a <radical>mohawk</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> means the <kanji>enemy</kanji> is nearby. You are from the dreadlock tribe and the mohawk tribe is your enemy. You’re deep in the heart of battle and winter has fallen. Now is the time to take out the enemy.
You see a <radical>tsunami</radical> that's <radical>simultaneous</radical> (with another tsunami, I assume) and you know the world is about to <kanji>come to an end</kanji>.

A <radical>grain</radical> <radical>woman</radical> is a woman who talks about grain with other women on a <kanji>committee</kanji>. Together they're known as the Committee of Grain Women. What does this committee discuss, you wonder.

If there’s <radical>grass</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and <radical>fins</radical> in your <radical>hand</radical>, you need to <kanji>raise</kanji> that hand up to the sky. You’re in the middle of a fisherman’s ritual, which can only be performed on grassy ground. You take fish fins from the previous year, and raise them up to the sky in order to ensure a good fishing harvest.
I hereby cut your assets in <radical>half</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical>, says the <kanji>judge</kanji>. At someone's divorce proceedings. Ah, the oldest judge trick in the book.

<radical>Cow</radical>s, using nothing more than a <radical>towel</radical> and a <radical>knife</radical>, have taken <kanji>control</kanji> of the world. Their <kanji>system</kanji> of control is brutal — payback for how we humans have treated them, I guess.
You use a special <radical>spear</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> to give yourself the <radical>power</radical> to do all of your <kanji>task</kanji>s.

If a <radical>tree</radical> is growing out of a <radical>top hat</radical> you need to <kanji>inspect</kanji> it to find out why and how this happened. You should probably <kanji>investigate</kanji> the area too. I mean, how could a tree grow out of a top hat anyway? Seems suspicious.
Taking out your <radical>thread</radical>, you sew together the <radical>public</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>s to make them <kanji>whole</kanji> again.
If you <radical>say</radical> a new <radical>weapon</radical> idea out loud, then it will be <kanji>establish</kanji>ed immediately.
The <radical>next</radical> <radical>shellfish</radical> will be yours, but this shellfish will be mine. These are the <kanji>resources</kanji> we have to share and distribute.

Under a <radical>tree</radical>, a broken <radical>arrow</radical> protrudes from a <radical>turkey</radical>. It was fighting for the <kanji>rights</kanji> of its fellow turkeys, and was mortally wounded in the process.
The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>cow</radical> tribe is too important to deal with small <kanji>matter</kanji>s and trivial <kanji>affair</kanji>s.
A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming for the <radical>cliff</radical> made of <radical>tofu</radical>, but there is a special <kanji>sect</kanji> that protects this tofu cliff.

You have a scene going on inside your <radical>head</radical>. It is of a pair of <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> atop a <radical>mountain</radical>. No. It is not just one pair of horns. It is many. So many that they create a giant <kanji>hill</kanji> atop the mountain, which is already pretty high.

The <radical>life</radical> <radical>thread</radical> is an <kanji>element</kanji> essential to all living things. This thread of life joins all things together, providing an essential relationship between all life. This element is all that holds this world together.

A <radical>lion</radical> harvesting <radical>rice</radical> uses an <radical>axe</radical> to <kanji>cut off</kanji> the tops of the stalks. The lion is roaming the rice fields using his axe to harvest the rice. He does so by cutting off the part of the rice stalks he needs.

If you use your <radical>fingers</radical> to point when you <radical>compare</radical> things you're really just throwing around <kanji>criticism</kanji>. You should never need to point fingers when you're just comparing things. If you're pointing and picking and being mean, that's criticism.

Both a <radical>leader</radical> and a <radical>king</radical> have a <kanji>duty</kanji> to protect their people. A good leader always protects his followers, and a good king always protects his subjects. This is their duty.
You see a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>squid</radical> on it, so you get closer to <kanji>examine</kanji> it.
A <radical>winter</radical> <radical>tree</radical> is only a winter tree due to a <kanji>clause</kanji> in its tree contract.

The <radical>life</radical> of a <radical>shellfish</radical> is filled with <kanji>blame</kanji>. They take the blame for everything from food poisoning and allergies, to cutting people's feet on beaches.
You only have a <radical>few</radical> <radical>eye</radical>s so you need to <kanji>conserve</kanji> what's left.
The <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>mask</radical> is a mask which, when put on, will greatly <kanji>increase</kanji> the amount of dirt.

Some of your <radical>grain</radical> has just been taken by a <radical>guard</radical>. This is the <kanji>tax</kanji> you pay for living in this town. Back in the day, grain was used like currency, so it makes sense that guards went around collecting grain tax.
<radical>Building</radical>s hold <radical>festival</radical>s on special <kanji>occasion</kanji>s.

Whatever people <radical>say</radical> to you will be carved by a <radical>blade</radical> into your <radical>heart</radical>. Sounds cruel, but it's a way to make you <kanji>recognize</kanji> their power.
The kanji and the radical are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. <radical>Righteousness</radical> is as <kanji>righteousness</kanji> does, right?
<radical>Sheep</radical> are always looking at the <radical>next</radical> animal, full of <kanji>envy</kanji> and <kanji>jealousy</kanji>.
All the <radical>world</radical>'s <radical>shellfish</radical> are yours to <kanji>receive</kanji>.

Beside your <radical>mouth</radical> you hold your <radical>cross</radical> as you pray for all your wishes to <kanji>come true</kanji>. Perhaps some divine power will <kanji>grant</kanji> what you wish for?
